background-color: transparent;"><font style="font-size: 24px;"><strong>EXPERT OPINION: A SPOT ON A COW</strong></font></p><p style="line-height: 18px;"><font color="#000000"><font style="font-size: 16px;"><font face="Trebuchet MS,sans-serif"><em>Content Contributor:</em></font> <font face="Trebuchet MS,sans-serif">Antoinette Kavanaugh, Ph.D., ABPP</font></font></font><br></p><p style="line-height: 18px;"><font color="#000000" face="Trebuchet MS,sans-serif" style="font-size: 16px;">At a recent family reunion in North Carolina, I was having breakfast with my aunt and her family. At one point, her kids shared a story about while growing up, they would go to events like the state fair and be one of the few families of color present. They would look at each other, smile, and say “Spot on a cow.” This is how they acknowledged that they were some of the few people of color at an event or outing. In this brief essay I will explain how being a <em>spot on a cow</em> led to my becoming a forensic psychologist and how it continues to shape the way I conceptualize and conduct forensic interviews.</font><br></p><p style="line-height: 18px;"><font color="#000000" face="Trebuchet MS,sans-serif" style="font-size: 16px;">To read the column, please click <a href="https://ap-ls.wildapricot.org/resources/EmailTemplates/2019_01%20January%20AP-LS%20Newsletter/ExpertOpinion1_19.pdf" target="_blank">here</a>.</font></p><p style="line-height: 22px;"><font color="#000000" face="Trebuchet MS,sans-serif"><br></font></p><p style="line-height: 22px;"><font color="#000000" face="Trebuchet MS,sans-serif" style="font-size: 24px;"><strong>RESEARCH BRIEFS</strong></font><br></p><p style="line-height: 18px;"><font color="#000000" face="Trebuchet MS,sans-serif">Take a look at the latest research briefs for short summaries of the latest articles relevant to psychology-law.&nbsp;</font><br></p><p style="line-height: 18px;"><font color="#000000" face="Trebuchet MS,sans-serif">To read the research briefs, please click <a href="https://ap-ls.wildapricot.org/resources/EmailTemplates/2019_01%20January%20AP-LS%20Newsletter/ResearchBriefs1_19.pdf" target="_blank">here</a>.</font></p><p style="margin: 0px 0px 10.66px; padding: 14px 8px 0px; background-image: none; background-repeat: repeat;" data-cellinner="cell4"><div id="idEditableArea_1480696629541_cell4" data-innereditablearea="cell4"><p style="line-height: 22px;"><font face="Trebuchet MS,sans-serif" style="font-size: 24px;"><strong>LHB IS GOING GREEN IN 2019</strong></font></p><p style="line-height: 18px;"><font face="Trebuchet MS,sans-serif">In August 2017, the Division 41 Executive Committee unanimously voted to renew its lucrative contract with the American Psychological Association to publish <em>Law and Human Behavior</em> through 2023. One important change in the new contract is that AP-LS members will no longer receive a complimentary print subscription to the journal beginning with the first issue of Volume 43 in February 2019.</font><br></p><p style="line-height: 18px;"><font face="Trebuchet MS,sans-serif">To access current and past issues of <em>LHB</em>, AP-LS members should log into <span style="background-color: white;"><a href="https://my.apa.org/apa/idm/login.seam?ERIGHTS_TARGET=/portal/home.seam"><font color="#0000ff">MyAPA</font></a></span> <span style="background-color: white;"><font color="#000000">using the email address they have on file with the division. All AP-LS members have a MyAPA account even if they are not members of the American Psychological Association.</font></span></font><br></p><p style="line-height: 18px;"><span style="background-color: white;"><font color="#000000" face="Trebuchet MS,sans-serif">AP-LS members who wish to continue receiving a print subscription of <em>LHB</em> should contact APA directly.
